column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

input.description:
Standard step input; single source with default name "source".

If undefined, the default output of the previous step will be used (if available).
If no previous step is available, this will remain undefined

Bin.description: Describes a data bin in terms of inclusive lower bound and count of values in the bin.

clamped.description:
If true, values outside of the min/max boundaries will be clamped to those
boundaries rather than +/-Infinity.

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

fixedcount.description:
Fixed number of bins.
Note that the bin placements are inclusive of the bottom boundary and exclusive of the top boundary -
this means there is always one extra bin for the max value when using fixed count.

max.description:
Max boundary to categorize values into.
If cell values are above this, they will default to +Infinity unless clamped.

min.description:
Min boundary to categorize values into.
If cell values are below this, they will default to -Infinity unless clamped.

printRange.description:
If true, the range for each bin will be printed as the cell value instead of the truncated numeric value.
This is useful for treating the

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.
Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

Category.description: Describes a nomincal category in terms of category name and count of values in the category.

CodebookSchema.description:
This contains all of the field-level details for interpreting a dataset,
including data types, mapping, and metadata.
Note that with persisted metadata and field examples, a dataset can often be visualized
and described to the user without actually loading the source file.
resource profile: 'codebook'

fields.description: The per-field encodings. These contain interpretive information about the data.

homepage.description: URL to a public webpage that describes this resource.

id.description:
Generated guid, immutable.
This can be used for stable referencing.

name.description:
User-specified name. This will serve as the local id (i.e., like a filename.) and should be URI-compatible.
This should be editable, just like any other filename on a file system.

path.description:
URI-compliant path to the resource (local or remote).
If array-valued, this points to a list of files that comprise the dataset (e.g., for splitting very large tables).

profile.description:
Defines the resource type.
Known resource types should have accommpanying processors and rendering components.
Unknown resource types can be interrogated to determine if the format is understandable by an existing component.
Note that this could be inferred from $schema, but a simple string here is easier to deal with in code.

sources.description:
List of resources that underly this resource.
This gives us the ability to create hierarchical or linked structures
to represent complex combinations.
For example, a parent resource can have source tables, a workflow, and a table schema that all combine
to create a fully-realized, strongly typed, and transformed output table.
Entire Resource objects may be embedded here, or a string path to the Resource definition JSON.

title.description: Friendly name of the resource. Used for display only.

enum.description: Strict list of allowed values in the column.

maxLength.description: For strings or arrays, this is the maximum allowed length of values.

maximum.description: For numbers or dates, this is the maximum allowed value.

minLength.description: For strings or arrays, this is the minimum allowed length of values.

minimum.description: For numbers or dates, this is the minimum allowed value.

pattern.description: RegExp pattern that string values must match.

required.description: Indicates that this field is required (not nullable).

unique.description: Indicates that every value in this column must be unique.

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

radix.description: Optional radix to use for parsing strings into ints

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

type.description:
Indicates whether the filter should be directly against a value,
or against the value of another column

value.description:
Comparison value for the column.
Not required if the operator is self-defining (e.g., 'is empty')

DataFormat.description:
Base format the data is stored within.
This will expand to include additional formats such as Arrow and Parquet over time.
TODO: we've seen a number of examples in the wild using JSON Lines https://jsonlines.org/

DataNature.description:
Indicates the expected general layout of the data.
This could be used to provide validation hints.
For example, microdata must have one row per subject.
TODO: "timeseries" as distinct from "panel"? others?

DataOrientation.description:
Indicates the orientation of the data within the file.

Most CSV data files are 'values' (row-oriented).

JSON files can commonly be either.
Records are probably more common, though require more space due to replication of keys.
Apache Arrow or Parquet are columnar.
This nearly aligns with pandas:
https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/io.html#json

A key difference (which probably needs resolved) is that we don't yet support the notion of an index.
See their example for "columns" or "index" orientation, which is a nested structure.

Example JSON formats:
 values: [
     ["colA", "colB"],
     ["valueA1", "valueA2"],
     ["valueA2", "valueB2"]
 ]
 records:
     [\{
         colA: valueA1,
         colB: valueB1
     \}, \{
         colA: valueA2,
         colB: valueB2
     \}]
 columnar: 
     \{
         colA: [valueA1, valueA2],
         colB: [valueB1, valueB2]
     \}

DataShape.description: Defines parameters for understanding the logical structure of data contents.

nature.description: Defines the expected nature of the dataset

orientation.description:
Data orientation.
Default: "values" is the only valid option if the format is csv, "records" is default if JSON.

DataTableSchema.description:
This defines the table-containing resource type.
A dataset can be embedded directly using the `data` property,
or it can be linked to a raw file using the `path`.
If the latter, optional format and parsing options can be applied to aid interpreting the file contents.
resource profile: 'datatable'

columns.description: Number of columns in the data.

data.description: Option to embed the data directly in the JSON descriptor.

format.description:
File format of the resource to inform load/parse.
Note that if the data property is present, this is assumed to be "JSON".
Default: "csv".

homepage.description: URL to a public webpage that describes this resource.

id.description:
Generated guid, immutable.
This can be used for stable referencing.

name.description:
User-specified name. This will serve as the local id (i.e., like a filename.) and should be URI-compatible.
This should be editable, just like any other filename on a file system.

parser.description: Parser options for interpreting a CSV or other text file that needs parse instruction.

path.description:
URI-compliant path to the resource (local or remote).
If array-valued, this points to a list of files that comprise the dataset (e.g., for splitting very large tables).

profile.description:
Defines the resource type.
Known resource types should have accommpanying processors and rendering components.
Unknown resource types can be interrogated to determine if the format is understandable by an existing component.
Note that this could be inferred from $schema, but a simple string here is easier to deal with in code.

rows.description: Number of rows in the data.

shape.description: Defines the shape and structure of stored data.

sources.description:
List of resources that underly this resource.
This gives us the ability to create hierarchical or linked structures
to represent complex combinations.
For example, a parent resource can have source tables, a workflow, and a table schema that all combine
to create a fully-realized, strongly typed, and transformed output table.
Entire Resource objects may be embedded here, or a string path to the Resource definition JSON.

title.description: Friendly name of the resource. Used for display only.

typeHints.description:
Options for converting string values to strict types.
Note that options related to data typing only apply if type detection is turned on.
Otherwise all cell values are treated as strings.
Defaults based on pandas: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/io.html#csv-text-files

DataType.description:
Explicit data type of the value (i.e., for a column or property).
TODO: clarify/update null/undefined

column1.description: Column on the left side of the operation

column2.description: Column on the right side of the operation

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

input.description: The inputs that must be bound; "source" & "other".

other.description: The secondary input, which must be specified

source.description: The primary input, which must be specified

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

value.description: A cell/property value of any type.

Field.description:
Contains the full schema definition and metadata for a data field (usually a table column).
This includes the required data type, various data nature and rendering properties, potential
validation rules, and mappings from a data dictionary.

constraints.description: Validation constraints for the values in the field to adhere to.

derivedFrom.description:
Provenance hints for the source of this field.
For example, categorical fields are often onehot encoded into new binary columns,
this would link back to the original categorical.

example.description: Single example of a valid data value for the field.

exclude.description: Indicates that this field from the dataset should be excluded from computations and display.

format.description:
Describes the semantic or parsing format for the values.
This is based on JSONSchema. See https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/json-schema-validation.html#name-vocabularies-for-semantic-c
TODO: JSONSchema is pretty flexible here, and we should align with it. For example, there are standard string (uri, email, ip-address, etc.)
that define known formats. However, you can also link out to any arbitrary schema that validates a data value.
JSONSchema also uses the format field to describe date and time notation. Because dates are not a valid JSON type,
they are represented as type = string, but format = date, time, date-time, or duration.
We use the type in running code, so it seems appropriate to keep the expanded list, but maybe this can contain parsing
instructions (e.g., a pattern) for converting date/time strings into values.
https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/json-schema-validation.html#name-defined-formats

inverse.description:
Indicates that values are mapped inverse to typical expectation, and may need to be displayed in the opposite direction.
Closely related to nature, particular for categorical ordinal values.

mapping.description:
This provides a mapping between cell values and some other value.
Most commonly this is the core "data dictionary", whereby cell values are stored as numeric categories,
and the dictionary defines textual descriptions of the actual meaning.
If numeric, the keys are usually categorical ordinal or nominal.
String keys are often commonly used (for example, medical data often use short alphanumeric codes to represent diagnostic strings).

metadata.description:
Detailed statistical metadata for the field.
Also convenient way to persist so expensive recomputing can be avoided.

name.description:
User-specified name. This will serve as the local id (i.e., like a filename.) and should be URI-compatible.
This should be editable, just like any other filename on a file system.

nature.description:
Data nature. This is primarily applicable to numbers, which have different characters that define how we should display them in charts.
default: continuous
TODO: there is a large block of nature-related content in CauseDis. is some of this transient application state? how much do we need to carry in a schema?

tags.description: Optional descriptive tags for the field.

title.description: Friendly name of the resource. Used for display only.

type.description:
Strict type of the field. Note that columns may not mix types in their rows for most of the data formats we use.
Default: 'string'

unit.description:
QUDT code for the variable unit (i.e., meters, pounds, etc.).
https://qudt.org/2.1/vocab/unit

unitDescription.description: Description of the unit for friendly display.

FieldAggregateOperation.description:
This is the subset of aggregate functions that can operate
on a single field so we don't accommodate additional args.
See https://uwdata.github.io/arquero/api/op#aggregate-functions

FieldMetadata.description: Holds core metadata/stats for a data field.

bins.description: Computed histogram bins for numeric fields.

categories.description: List of unique categories for string fields.

count.description: Count of valid values in the column (excluding invalid, null, etc.)

distinct.description: Count of unique values in the column

invalid.description: Count of invalid/null values in the column

magnitude.description: Magnitude of the data, i.e., the absolute difference between the min and max values.

maximum.description:
Max value.
Note that this can be specified rather than computed, in which case it defines valid boundaries for the data values.

minimum.description:
Min value.
Note that this can be specified rather than computed, in which case it defines valid boundaries for the data values.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

value.description: Value to fill in the new column

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

to.description: Two-element array of names for the output [key, value]

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

value.description: Value to fill in empty cells

InputColumnListArgs.description: Base interface for a number of operations that work on a column list.

columns.description: Map of old column to new column names

on.description:
Column names to join with.
If only one is specified, it will use for both tables.
If none are specified, all matching column names will be used.

Column names to join with.
If only one is specified, it will use for both tables.
If none are specified, all matching column names will be used.

delimiter.description:
This is only necessary if mergeStrategy.Concat is used.
If it is not supplied, the values are just mashed together.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

node.description: The id of the input node to bind to

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

prefix.description: Optional prefixes for the output column names

orders.description: List of ordering instructions to apply

ParseType.description: This is a subset of data types available for parsing operations

ParserOptions.description: Parsing options for delimited files. This is a mix of the options from pandas and spark.

comment.description:
Character that denotes a comment. Lines that begin with this character are ignored.
Default: none.

escapeChar.description:
String to use for escaping quotes.
Default: none

header.description:
Indicates that the first row of the file contains column header names.
If false, `names` should be supplied, otherwise incrementing numbers will be assigned as header names.
Default: true

lineTerminator.description:
Character that indicates the end of a line (row).
Default: \\r, \\r\\n, or \\n

names.description:
List of column names to use.
If this is not supplied, column names will be inferred from the first row of the data.

quoteChar.description:
Character to use for quoting strings.
Default: "

readRows.description:
Number of rows to read from the data, starting at skip_rows (honors skipBlankLines).
Default: Infinity

skipBlankLines.description:
Skip blank lines when reading file.
Default: true.

skipRows.description:
Number of rows to skip from the start of the data (honors skipBlankLines).
Default: 0

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

mapping.description:
Mapping of old value to new for the recoding.
Note that the key must be coercable to a string for map lookup.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

ResourceSchema.description:
Parent class for any resource type understood by the system.
Any object type that extends from Resouce is expected to have a standalone schema published.
For project state, this can be left as generic as possible for now.

homepage.description: URL to a public webpage that describes this resource.

id.description:
Generated guid, immutable.
This can be used for stable referencing.

name.description:
User-specified name. This will serve as the local id (i.e., like a filename.) and should be URI-compatible.
This should be editable, just like any other filename on a file system.

path.description:
URI-compliant path to the resource (local or remote).
If array-valued, this points to a list of files that comprise the dataset (e.g., for splitting very large tables).

profile.description:
Defines the resource type.
Known resource types should have accommpanying processors and rendering components.
Unknown resource types can be interrogated to determine if the format is understandable by an existing component.
Note that this could be inferred from $schema, but a simple string here is easier to deal with in code.

sources.description:
List of resources that underly this resource.
This gives us the ability to create hierarchical or linked structures
to represent complex combinations.
For example, a parent resource can have source tables, a workflow, and a table schema that all combine
to create a fully-realized, strongly typed, and transformed output table.
Entire Resource objects may be embedded here, or a string path to the Resource definition JSON.

title.description: Friendly name of the resource. Used for display only.

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

proportion.description:
If table size is unknown ahead of time, specify a proportion of rows to sample.
If size is specified, it will be used instead, otherwise computed from this
proportion using the table.numRows()

size.description:
Number of rows to sample from the table.
This takes precedence over proportion.

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

delimiter.description: Delimiter to use when converting string cell values into an array with String.split

onehot.description:
Indicates that a onehot-style spread should be performed.
This maps all unique cell values to new columns and sets the output cell value to a binary 1/0 based on column match.
This is in contrast to the default spread, which just maps array values to column by index.

id.description: A unique identifier for this step

TypeHints.description:
Configuration values for interpreting data types when parsing a delimited file.
By default, all values are read as strings - applying these type hints can derive primitive types from the strings.

dateFormat.description:
Default date format to use when parsing dates. The Codebook can override this at the column level.
Default: yyyy-MM-dd
TODO: spark has a separate config for datetime. Do we care?

decimal.description:
Character to use when parsing decimal numbers.
Default: .

infinity.description:
Strings to parse as negative and positive infinity.
Default: case insensitive ["-inf", "inf"].

naValues.description:
Strings to consider NaN or null.
Default:
['-1.#IND', '1.#QNAN', '1.#IND', '-1.#QNAN', '#N/A N/A', '#N/A', 'N/A', 'n/a', 'NA', '<NA>', '#NA', 'NULL', 'null', 'NaN', '-NaN', 'nan', '-nan', '']

thousands.description:
For large numbers that have been written with a thousands separator, you can set the thousands keyword to a string of length 1 so that integers will be parsed correctly.
By default, numbers with a thousands separator will be parsed as strings.
Default: none.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

VariableNature.description:
Describes the semantic shape of a variable.
This has particular effect on how we display and compare data,
such as using line charts for continuous versus bar charts for categorical.
This mostly applies to numeric variables, but strings for instance can be categorial.

input.description:
The step inputs; a required "source" and optional, variadic "others". If this is a
string, it is used to bind the primary input.

column.description: Name of the input column for columnnar operations.

to.description: Name of the output column to receive the operation's result.

WindowFunction.description:
These are operations that perform windowed compute.
See https://uwdata.github.io/arquero/api/op#window-functions

WorkflowSchema.description:
The root wrangling workflow specification.
resource profile: 'workflow'

homepage.description: URL to a public webpage that describes this resource.

input.description: A list of input names that are expected to be provided in addition to the workflow steps

sources.description: The sources that compose a table bundle.
